conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_B. School_B is my first-choice school, and if admitted I will commit enthusiastically. I’m especially interested in your academic rigor and school culture, and I’m ready to contribute positively in class and in activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_B, so I should apply immediately rather than risk losing the only seat. Although School_B’s priority list ranks me 3rd (behind Student_D and Student_A), applying now is still optimal because any delay only increases the chance the seat is taken. I’ll send a clear [APPLY] emphasizing strong fit and commitment to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_B is your first choice. We appreciate your interest in our academic rigor and community.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_B. Congratulations—we look forward to having you join us and contribute to our campus.

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_B, my true priority ranks Student_D and Student_A above Student_B. However, in round 1 I only have an application from Student_B. Looking at students' preferences: Student_D ranks School_B 3rd (after School_C and School_A), Student_A ranks School_B 4th, Student_C ranks School_B 3rd, Student_E ranks School_B 2nd. So higher-priority candidates are less likely to apply to me early, especially Student_D and Student_A. If I reject Student_B now, I risk ending up unmatched or matched with a lower-priority student later. Since Student_B is still relatively high on my list (3rd) and is explicitly committing with first-choice enthusiasm, accepting secures a good outcome within quota 1.

conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_C and I’m formally applying. School_D is my first choice because I value your academic environment and would be excited to contribute strongly in class and school activities. If admitted, I will commit to enrolling. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_D. I also have relatively strong priority there (School_D ranks me 3rd), giving me a realistic chance if I apply immediately before the seat is taken. I will apply and emphasize fit and commitment to increase acceptance likelihood.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission, and we appreciate your commitment to enroll.

Welcome to School_D.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_C is #3 on School_D’s true priority list (after Student_D and Student_E). However, Student_C has applied to us as their #1 choice and will commit, which makes acceptance likely stable. Student_D (our #1) ranks School_D last and is very unlikely to apply here; Student_E ranks School_D 4th and is more likely to match with School_C/B/A first. Given quota=1 and only Student_C in the inbox this round, rejecting risks ending unmatched or later accepting a lower-priority student. Accepting Student_C secures a high-priority, committed match now.

conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions Committee—I'm Student_D. School_C is my first-choice school, and I’m applying because I strongly want to join your community. I’m especially interested in the learning environment and would be ready to commit immediately if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd after Student_C and Student_B). If I apply immediately, I have a decent chance unless both Student_C and Student_B also apply and are accepted ahead of me. Since it’s round 1 and School_C is my true first choice, I should apply now and clearly express commitment to increase the likelihood they pick me if they have discretion.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We appreciate your clear commitment and interest in our community.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_C. [ACCEPT]

If you would like, please reply with any questions about next steps and enrollment logistics.
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority is Student_C > Student_B > Student_D > Student_E > Student_A. I have quota 1. Student_D is applying now and ranks 3rd on my list, and School_C is Student_D’s first choice, so accepting would lock in a solid match. However, Student_C (my top choice) prefers School_D then School_A then School_B then School_C, so they are unlikely to apply to me in round 1 and may never reach me if accepted elsewhere. Student_B ranks School_C last, so unlikely to apply. Student_E ranks School_C first and may apply soon; Student_E is below Student_D on my priority list. Given the low likelihood of receiving Student_C or Student_B, and that Student_D is a high-ranked candidate who is ready to commit, accepting now maximizes my expected outcome and avoids the risk of ending unmatched or with a lower-priority student.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_A is my first choice, and I’m formally applying. I’m highly motivated to enroll if admitted and would be excited to contribute academically and to school activities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A, but I’m only 3rd in School_A’s priority list (behind Student_B and Student_D). I should still apply immediately because getting School_A is my best possible outcome, and there’s a chance higher-priority students commit elsewhere. A direct [APPLY] maximizes my chance to secure the top school early if they are willing to accept now.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_A,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_A. We’re excited about the possibility of you joining our community and contributing both academically and through school activities.

Please confirm your intent to enroll, and we’ll share the next steps for enrollment.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: School_A’s true priority ranks Student_A (3rd) above Student_E (4th) but below Student_B (1st) and Student_D (2nd). In round 1, only Student_A and Student_E applied to us. If we accept Student_A now, we fill our sole seat and cannot take Student_B or Student_D if they apply later. Check likelihood: Student_B’s top choice is School_B (School_B ranks Student_B 3rd) and Student_D’s top choice is School_C (School_C ranks Student_D 3rd). Both could be accepted elsewhere, so waiting risks ending with only lower-ranked options or an unfilled seat. However, Student_A is our 3rd choice and is highly committed (School_A is their 1st). Accepting now secures a strong match and avoids the risk that Student_B/D never approach or get locked in elsewhere before we can engage them. Given quota 1 and no ability to hold, accept Student_A.

conversation.message: Dear School_A Admissions, I’m Student_E. I’m very interested in joining School_A and believe I would be a strong fit for your academic environment and expectations. If offered a seat, I will gladly accept and commit to enrolling. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but I am only 4th in School_C’s priority list (behind Student_C, Student_B, Student_D). Since everyone applies simultaneously, applying to School_C now is likely to be rejected if any of those higher-priority students apply. My next choice is School_B, where I am 5th (last), also very unlikely. School_A is my 3rd choice and I am 4th there, but importantly Student_B (School_A’s top) prefers School_B first, Student_D prefers School_C first, and Student_A prefers School_A first—so there is a plausible path where School_A is not flooded by multiple higher-priority applicants in round 1, giving me a non-zero chance. To maximize the probability of securing a reasonably high option early, I will apply to School_A with a concise, sincere commitment message.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for your strong interest in School_A. At this time, we have already filled our available seat and are unable to offer you admission.

We sincerely appreciate your interest and wish you the very best in the rest of the process.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: Student_E applied, but School_A has already matched with Student_A and the remaining quota is 0. Per rules, with quota 0 I must reject any new [APPLY] regardless of priority. Student_E is on our true priority list (4th), but we cannot admit beyond capacity this round.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

I’m Student_E, and I would like to formally apply to School_E. I’m genuinely excited about the opportunity to join your community, and I believe I would contribute positively to the school’s academic environment. If offered admission, I will accept and commit to enrolling.

Thank you very much for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched. School_E is on my true preference list (though lowest), and applying now is better than risking being unmatched. I will signal strong commitment to improve acceptance chances.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for your interest in School_E. After reviewing our current admissions priorities and available capacity for this round, we are not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate you reaching out and wish you the very best in your placement process.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_E, my true priority ranks Student_E 4th (A, C, B, E, D). I have quota 1 and only Student_E has applied to me so far. However, Student_E ranks School_E last, so they may only be applying as a fallback and could still try to match elsewhere if not immediately accepted. Meanwhile, higher-priority students (A/C/B) are likely to apply to their top choices first; School_E is last for A and C as well, and 4th for B, so they may come later if rejected elsewhere. If I accept Student_E now, I lock in a lower-priority match and lose the chance to take a higher-priority student who might arrive in later rounds. Since I prefer leaving unfilled over taking someone outside my list (not an issue here) but still want the highest-ranked feasible match, the best strategy is to reject now and wait for potential higher-priority applicants.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

Thank you for considering my earlier application. I’m writing to reaffirm my strong interest in School_E and to ask if you would reconsider me for the remaining open seat. If offered admission, I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling.

I would be grateful for the opportunity to join your community.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched in the active list, and it is on my preference list (though lowest). Since I prefer matching to remaining unmatched and there are no other options, I should re-apply with a clear commitment and a concise update, signaling strong interest and readiness to enroll immediately if admitted.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E and for reaffirming your commitment. At this time, we are not able to offer you admission for our remaining seat.

We appreciate your persistence and encourage you to continue pursuing the best available option in this process.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). We still have quota 1 and are currently unmatched, but accepting Student_E now would lock our only seat and prevent a potential later match with higher-priority Student_A/Student_C/Student_B, who are all ranked above Student_E. Given students’ preferences, Student_A ranks School_E last, Student_C ranks it last, Student_B ranks it 4th—so higher-priority candidates are less likely to apply early, but may come later if rejected elsewhere. Since we prefer leaving the seat unfilled over taking someone outside the list (not relevant here) and we can still wait for higher-priority candidates, the best strategic move is to reject Student_E again this round to preserve capacity for A/C/B. If no higher-priority candidates appear in later rounds, we can reconsider Student_E then.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

Thank you again for considering my earlier applications. Since School_E is still available, I wanted to ask if there is any realistic path for me to be considered for the remaining seat at this stage. If there are specific criteria or information you would need from me (e.g., confirmation of immediate enrollment, updated achievements, or any other requirement), I’m ready to provide it right away.

I remain prepared to commit immediately if admitted.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[TALK]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though ranked 5th). I have already been rejected twice, so another identical APPLY is unlikely to change the outcome. A TALK message can reopen dialogue, ask what would make me admissible given their priorities, and signal immediate commitment if a seat is still genuinely available—without forcing an immediate accept/reject decision.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your message and for your continued interest in School_E. At this stage, we are still prioritizing the possibility of filling our remaining seat with applicants who are higher on our priority list. Because of that, there isn’t a specific additional document or “extra criterion” that would change your position immediately.

That said, if we reach a point where the seat remains open after we have resolved opportunities with those higher-priority candidates, we would be able to reconsider you. If you remain interested, the practical path is to check back and submit an [APPLY] again in a later round if you are still unmatched.

In the meantime, I encourage you to continue pursuing other options as well so you don’t lose time in the process.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: School_E has 1 seat and true priority order A > C > B > E > D. Student_E is 4th on our list, and we have already rejected two APPLY attempts from Student_E, signaling we are holding the seat for higher-priority candidates. Given the market, Student_A and Student_C rank School_E last, but they may become unmatched later and could still apply; accepting Student_E now would forfeit the chance to match with A/C/B, which are strictly preferred. Student_E is only initiating TALK, so we can maintain optionality by responding with TALK, clarifying that reconsideration depends on availability after higher-priority candidates have been processed, and encouraging them to keep other options active while they can re-apply later if still unmatched.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

I’m Student_E. Since School_E is still available this round, I would like to formally apply again for the remaining seat. If admitted, I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling.

If there is any update on whether the seat is likely to be offered to higher-priority candidates this round, I would appreciate any guidance—but regardless, please consider this my active application.

Sincerely,
Student_E

[APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though last). I have already been rejected twice, but School_E indicated I could be reconsidered if higher-priority candidates do not take the seat. To maximize my chance of getting any match rather than ending unmatched, I should re-apply now with a clear immediate-commitment signal and a polite check on whether the seat is still open.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E and for submitting your application again. At this time, we are still holding our remaining seat for the possibility of applicants who are higher on our priority list this cycle, so we are not able to offer you admission in this round.

If you remain unmatched in a later round and School_E still has an open seat, you are welcome to apply again.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). We still have quota 1 and are currently unmatched. Given all students’ preferences, Student_A ranks School_E last, Student_C ranks it last, Student_B ranks it 4th, and Student_D ranks it 4th—so higher-priority candidates are unlikely to apply here unless rejected elsewhere. However, accepting Student_E now would forfeit the chance (however small) to match with A/C/B later. With rounds remaining (5 of 30) and no competing applicants in this round’s inbox, the optimal strategy to maximize priority is to continue holding the seat and reject for now, consistent with prior communication, while inviting Student_E to reapply later if still unmatched.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

I’m Student_E, and I’m still unmatched this round. I would like to formally apply again to School_E for the remaining seat. If offered admission, I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling.

If you’re able to share any update on whether you expect a higher-priority candidate to take the seat this round (or whether the seat may be decided soon), I would appreciate the guidance. Regardless, please consider this my active application for this round.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (though last). Remaining unmatched is worse than accepting School_E, so I should keep applying while emphasizing immediate commitment and asking whether higher-priority candidates are still realistically in play this round.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued interest in School_E and for your clear commitment to enroll if admitted. Given our remaining capacity and the current stage of the process, we are able to offer you admission for our open seat.

Please confirm that you accept this offer and will enroll at School_E.

Sincerely,
School_E Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). Quota is 1 and currently unfilled. However, higher-priority students (A/C/B) all rank School_E last, making it very unlikely they will apply unless they are rejected everywhere else late in the process. Holding the seat longer risks ending unmatched if no one else applies. Student_E has repeatedly applied and credibly commits to enroll immediately, providing a secure fill with an acceptable-ranked student. Given round 6 and repeated evidence that higher-priority candidates are not approaching, accepting Student_E now maximizes expected outcome versus continued waiting.
